title: Prosecutor drop charges against Donald Trump over 2020 election interference and classified documents
summary: Special Counsel Jack Smith said the move was being made under a long-standing US Justice Department policy of not prosecuting a sitting president.

title: Discussions over sending European troops to Ukraine reignited
summary: With the prospect of American disengagement from Kyiv following Donald Trump's return to the White House, Paris and London are not ruling out leading a military coalition in Ukraine.

title: 'COPs are part of the barrier against the populist storm that is sweeping the planet'
summary: Despite minimal agreement and obstruction from oil-producing countries, the climate conference is proof that multilateralism is not dead according to sociologist Stefan Aykut, in an interview with 'Le Monde'.

title: France unveils new measures to combat violence against women
summary: The government has launched a new campaign to combat violence against women, which includes expanding the network of hospitals where victims can report incidents from 236 to 377 by the end of 2025.

title: Democrats and American celebrities, a zero-sum game
summary: The support of Billie Eilish, Beyoncé, Taylor Swift and Lady Gaga wasn't enough to turn the tide for Kamala Harris. As in Hillary Clinton's day, this show-business support fueled Donald Trump's anti-elite rhetoric.

title: Delusions of grandeur and a tragic night: The downfall of former business queen Aude de Thuin
summary: On the morning of June 4, in an apartment on Paris's prestigious Boulevard Haussmann, businessman Hubert Zieseniss was found dead, alongside his wife Aude de Thuin, who was alive but with her wrists slashed. The discovery cast a harsh light on the downfall of a flamboyant entrepreneur.

title: French mass rape trial: Prosecutors request maximum sentence for Dominique Pelicot
summary: After 11 weeks of hearing drew to a close last week, prosecutors must now decide on appropriate potential punishments for lead defendant Dominique Pelicot and the 49 other defendants, men aged 26 to 74 and from all walks of life.

title: Menendez brothers' fight for freedom postponed until January
summary: The Menendez brothers, imprisoned for over three decades, were at the center of a sensational 1990s trial that gripped the nation. Millions of Americans were riveted by the lurid details of the slayings of Jose and Kitty Menendez in their opulent Beverly Hills mansion.

title: Global rates of HIV cases and related deaths sharply declining
summary: These new results are marking significant progress in the fight against the disease, but HIV remains far from being stamped out, health experts warn ahead of World AIDS Day on Sunday.

title: Haiti: More than 40,000 flee Port-au-Prince violence in 10 days
summary: Soaring violence in Port-au-Prince has left at least 150 people dead, bringing the number of deaths in Haiti this year to over 4,500, according to a report released last week by the United Nations. "The latest upsurge in violence in Haiti's capital is a harbinger of worse to come," UN rights chief Volker Turk warned in a statement.

title: Three years after the worst migrant shipwreck in the Channel, crossings are more deadly than ever
summary: Thirty-one people died or disappeared when their dinghy sank on November 24, 2021, with no rescue services helping them. Despite an increase in police and sea rescue resources since then, the number of people trying to reach England in small boats has not abated and shipwrecks are multiplying.

title: Le Pen threatens to bring down French government over budget
summary: Asked on Monday after a meeting with the prime minister if her party would back a no-confidence motion, far-right leader Marine Le Pen replied: 'Of course.'

title: Difficult ceasefire negotiations in Lebanon amid escalation between Israel and Hezbollah
summary: Following Israeli strikes on Beirut on Saturday, the Shiite movement stepped up its response. This increased tension is hindering ceasefire talks initiated by the American Middle East envoy.

title: Eliane Heilbronn, the Chanel group family matriarch, has died
summary: Eliane Heilbronn was the lawyer who drafted famous creative director Karl Lagerfeld's contract with Chanel, as well as the mother of Alain and Gérard Wertheimer, discreet owners of the luxury group.

title: After the floods in northern France, a Michelin-starred chef fights to save his restaurant
summary: La Grenouillère has been unable to reopen since the river Canche burst its banks a year ago. This autumn, the water rose again, flooding the place that was still being renovated. To hold on to his team, Alexandre Gauthier has turned to projects in France and abroad.

title: To stay or not to stay on X, the big question for French media
summary: Following in the footsteps of The Guardian, France's regional media groups Ouest-France and Sud Ouest have decided to suspend their activity on Elon Musk's site. But some outlets argue the need to remain present on the platform.

title: Uruguay's left returns to power after moderate campaign
summary: Yamandu Orsi (left), won the presidential election on Sunday, November 24, in a run-off against Alvaro Delgado (center-right). While many countries in the region are experiencing a rise of the far right, Uruguay stands out as an exception.

title: Rekindled love: 'Life is cruel by only giving us this gift now'
summary: They met, fell in love and drifted apart. Then life brought them together again. Hélène, 77, shares her story with Gabriel, 83.

title: Pope slams conflicts in Ukraine and Palestinian territories
summary: In an unscripted remark made to diplomats, the pope blamed 'the arrogance of the invader' in 'Ukraine and Palestine,' days after he called for an investigation into claims Israel was conducting 'genocide' in Gaza.

title: Trump, saved by American voters, escapes federal prosecution for attempt to overturn 2020 election
summary: Special Counsel Jack Smith emphasized the 'unprecedented circumstances' and 'gravity of the crimes' at the heart of the indictments but had to back down in the face of the immunity the president-elect will enjoy once in office.

title: In East Jerusalem, a record number of homes destroyed to drive out Palestinian residents
summary: The Israeli authorities are speeding up the reshaping of annexed Arab neighborhoods by expelling their residents in the process. In this context, they recently demolished the Al-Bustan community center, a vital hub in Silwan that had been financed by France.

title: Trump vows massive tariffs on Mexico, Canada, and China on Day 1 of his presidency
summary: In a series of posts to his Truth Social account, Trump vowed to hit some of the United States' largest trading partners with sweeping taxes on all goods entering the country.

title: Japan: Large fire at rocket test site, no injuries reported
summary: The fire happened during a combustion test that began at around 8:30 am local time. About 30 seconds later, a large explosion was heard, and what appeared to be something on fire flew toward the sea.

title: The French obsession with Japanese whisky
summary: The fruit of century-old craftsmanship, Japanese malt was long kept a secret. Since the early 2000s, French consumers have played a key role in the export success of these alcoholic elixirs from the Asian archipelago.

title: Daniel Cohn-Bendit and Raphaël Glucksmann: 'How can we fail to see that the Israeli response violates the laws of war and tramples on international law?'
summary: At a time when the election of Donald Trump could bolster Benjamin Netanyahu in his murderous strategy, former and current MEPs assert that the ICC's arrest warrant against the Israeli prime minister is not antisemitic, and call on France to recognize the Palestinian state.

title: Paul Pogba: Six face trial in Paris for blackmailing footballer
summary: His brother Mathias is among the men accused of attempting to extort millions of euros from the footballer, who was even held at gunpoint.

title: In Queens, the 'New York Times' printing plant, a monster of steel and paper
summary: Hundreds of thousands of newspapers leave New York's largest daily newspaper printing plant every day. A place that French photographer Tom de Peyret had the opportunity to visit in 2018.

title: Pro-Russian far-right candidate makes unexpected breakthrough in Romania's presidential election
summary: Calin Georgescu, who is an admirer of Vladimir Putin and has expressed contempt for NATO and the European Union, came on top of the first round. Social-democrat prime minister Marcel Ciolacu, who came in third place, was eliminated.
